org.gearvrf

Class GVRAssetLoader

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.GVRAssetLoader

  • public final class GVRAssetLoader
extends java.lang.Object
    GVRAssetLoader provides methods for importing 3D models and making them available through instances of GVRAssimpImporter.

    Supports importing models from an application's resources (both assets and res/raw), from directories on the device's SD card and URLs on the internet that the application has permission to read.

    • Method Detail

      • loadTexture

        public GVRTexture loadTexture(GVRAndroidResource resource,
                              GVRTextureParameters textureParameters)
        Loads file placed in the assets folder, as a GVRBitmapTexture with the user provided texture parameters.

        Note that this method may take hundreds of milliseconds to return: unless the texture is quite tiny, you probably don't want to call this directly from your onStep() callback as that is called once per frame, and a long call will cause you to miss frames. For large images, you should use loadTexture(GVRAndroidResource, GVRAndroidResource.TextureCallback).

        This method automatically scales large images to fit the GPU's restrictions and to avoid out of memory errors.

        Parameters:
        resource - Basically, a stream containing a bitmap texture. The GVRAndroidResource class has six constructors to handle a wide variety of Android resource types. Taking a GVRAndroidResource here eliminates six overloads.
        textureParameters - The texture parameter object which has all the values that were provided by the user for texture enhancement. The GVRTextureParameters class has methods to set all the texture filters and wrap states. If this parameter is nullo, default texture parameters are used.
        Returns:
        The file as a texture, or null if the file can not be decoded into a Bitmap.
        See Also:
        getDefaultTextureParameters()

      • loadTexture

        public GVRTexture loadTexture(GVRAndroidResource resource)

      • loadTexture

        public void loadTexture(GVRAndroidResource resource,
                        GVRAndroidResource.TextureCallback callback,
                        GVRTextureParameters texparams,
                        int priority,
                        int quality,
                        boolean cacheEnabled)
        Loads a texture asynchronously. This method can detect whether the resource file holds a compressed texture (GVRF currently supports ASTC, ETC2, and KTX formats: applications can add new formats by implementing GVRCompressedTextureLoader): if the file is not a compressed texture, it is loaded as a normal, bitmapped texture. This format detection adds very little to the cost of loading even a compressed texture, and it makes your life a lot easier: you can replace, say, res/raw/resource.png with res/raw/resource.etc2 without having to change any code.
        Parameters:
        callback - Before loading, GVRF may call stillWanted() several times (on a background thread) to give you a chance to abort a 'stale' load. Successful loads will call loaded() on the GL thread; any errors will call failed(), with no promises about threading.

        This method uses a throttler to avoid overloading the system. If the throttler has threads available, it will run this request immediately. Otherwise, it will enqueue the request, and call stillWanted() at least once (on a background thread) to give you a chance to abort a 'stale' load.

        Use loadFutureTexture(GVRAndroidResource) to avoid having to implement a callback.

        resource - Basically, a stream containing a texture file. The GVRAndroidResource class has six constructors to handle a wide variety of Android resource types. Taking a GVRAndroidResource here eliminates six overloads.
        texparams - GVRTextureParameters object containing texture sampler attributes.
        priority - This request's priority. Please see the notes on asynchronous priorities in the package description. Also, please note priorities only apply to uncompressed textures (standard Android bitmap files, which can take hundreds of milliseconds to load): compressed textures load so quickly that they are not run through the request scheduler.
        quality - The compressed texture quality parameter: should be one of GVRCompressedTexture.SPEED, GVRCompressedTexture.BALANCED, or GVRCompressedTexture.QUALITY, but other values are 'clamped' to one of the recognized values. Please note that this (currently) only applies to compressed textures; normal bitmapped textures don't take a quality parameter.
        cacheEnabled - true to enable texture cache, false and the texture is not added to the cache

      • loadTexture

        public void loadTexture(GVRAndroidResource resource,
                        GVRAndroidResource.TextureCallback callback,
                        GVRTextureParameters texparams,
                        int priority,
                        int quality)
        Loads a texture asynchronously. This method can detect whether the resource file holds a compressed texture (GVRF currently supports ASTC, ETC2, and KTX formats: applications can add new formats by implementing GVRCompressedTextureLoader): if the file is not a compressed texture, it is loaded as a normal, bitmapped texture. This format detection adds very little to the cost of loading even a compressed texture, and it makes your life a lot easier: you can replace, say, res/raw/resource.png with res/raw/resource.etc2 without having to change any code.
        Parameters:
        callback - Before loading, GVRF may call stillWanted() several times (on a background thread) to give you a chance to abort a 'stale' load. Successful loads will call loaded() on the GL thread; any errors will call failed(), with no promises about threading.

        This method uses a throttler to avoid overloading the system. If the throttler has threads available, it will run this request immediately. Otherwise, it will enqueue the request, and call stillWanted() at least once (on a background thread) to give you a chance to abort a 'stale' load.

        resource - Basically, a stream containing a texture file. The GVRAndroidResource class has six constructors to handle a wide variety of Android resource types. Taking a GVRAndroidResource here eliminates six overloads.

Please note that this (currently) only applies to compressed textures; normal bitmapped textures don't take a quality parameter.

      • loadTexture

        public void loadTexture(GVRAndroidResource resource,
                        GVRAndroidResource.TextureCallback callback)
        Loads a texture asynchronously with default priority and quality. This method can detect whether the resource file holds a compressed texture (GVRF currently supports ASTC, ETC2, and KTX formats: applications can add new formats by implementing GVRCompressedTextureLoader): if the file is not a compressed texture, it is loaded as a normal, bitmapped texture. This format detection adds very little to the cost of loading even a compressed texture, and it makes your life a lot easier: you can replace, say, res/raw/resource.png with res/raw/resource.etc2 without having to change any code.
        Parameters:
        callback - Before loading, GVRF may call stillWanted() several times (on a background thread) to give you a chance to abort a 'stale' load. Successful loads will call loaded() on the GL thread; any errors will call failed(), with no promises about threading.

        This method uses a throttler to avoid overloading the system. If the throttler has threads available, it will run this request immediately. Otherwise, it will enqueue the request, and call stillWanted() at least once (on a background thread) to give you a chance to abort a 'stale' load.

        Use loadFutureTexture(GVRAndroidResource) to avoid having to implement a callback.

        resource - Basically, a stream containing a texture file. The GVRAndroidResource class has six constructors to handle a wide variety of Android resource types. Taking a GVRAndroidResource here eliminates six overloads.

      • loadFutureTexture

        public java.util.concurrent.Future<GVRTexture> loadFutureTexture(GVRAndroidResource resource,
                                                                 int priority,
                                                                 int quality)
        Simple, high-level method to load a texture asynchronously, for use with GVRShaders.setMainTexture(Future) and GVRShaders.setTexture(String, Future).

        This method is significantly easier to use than org.gearvrf.GVRAssetLoader#loadTexture(GVRAndroidResource, TextureCallback, GVRTextureParameters, int, int) You don't have to implement a callback; you don't have to pay attention to the low-level details of attaching a GVRRenderData to your scene object. What's more, you don't even lose any functionality: Future.cancel(boolean) lets you cancel a 'stale' request, just like stillWanted() does. The flip side, of course, is that it is a bit more expensive: methods like GVRMaterial.setMainTexture(Future) use an extra thread from the thread pool to wait for the blocking Future.get() call. For modest numbers of loads, this overhead is acceptable - but thread creation is not free, and if your onInit() method fires of dozens of future loads, you may well see an impact.

        Parameters:
        resource - Basically, a stream containing a texture file. The GVRAndroidResource class has six constructors to handle a wide variety of Android resource types. Taking a GVRAndroidResource here eliminates six overloads.
        priority - This request's priority. Please see the notes on asynchronous priorities in the package description. Also, please note priorities only apply to uncompressed textures (standard Android bitmap files, which can take hundreds of milliseconds to load): compressed textures load so quickly that they are not run through the request scheduler.
        quality - The compressed texture quality parameter: should be one of GVRCompressedTexture.SPEED, GVRCompressedTexture.BALANCED, or GVRCompressedTexture.QUALITY, but other values are 'clamped' to one of the recognized values. Please note that this (currently) only applies to compressed textures; normal bitmapped textures don't take a quality parameter.
        Returns:
        A Future that you can pass to methods like GVRShaders.setMainTexture(Future)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If you 'abuse' request consolidation by passing the same GVRAndroidResource descriptor to multiple load calls.

        It's fairly common for multiple scene objects to use the same texture or the same mesh. Thus, if you try to load, say, R.raw.whatever while you already have a pending request for R.raw.whatever, it will only be loaded once; the same resource will be used to satisfy both (all) requests. This "consolidation" uses GVRAndroidResource.equals(Object), not == (aka "reference equality"): The problem with using the same resource descriptor is that if requests can't be consolidated (because the later one(s) came in after the earlier one(s) had already completed) the resource will be reloaded ... but the original descriptor will have been closed.

        Since:
        3.2

      • loadFutureTexture

        public java.util.concurrent.Future<GVRTexture> loadFutureTexture(GVRAndroidResource resource)
        Simple, high-level method to load a texture asynchronously, for use with GVRShaders.setMainTexture(Future) and GVRShaders.setTexture(String, Future). This method uses a default priority and a default render quality: use loadFutureTexture(GVRAndroidResource, int, int) to specify priority and render quality.

        This method is significantly easier to use than org.gearvrf.GVRAssetLoader#loadTexture(GVRAndroidResource, TextureCallback, GVRTextureParameters, int, int) : you don't have to implement a callback; you don't have to pay attention to the low-level details of attaching a GVRRenderData to your scene object. What's more, you don't even lose any functionality: Future.cancel(boolean) lets you cancel a 'stale' request, just like stillWanted() does. The flip side, of course, is that it is a bit more expensive: methods like GVRMaterial.setMainTexture(Future) use an extra thread from the thread pool to wait for the blocking Future.get() call. For modest numbers of loads, this overhead is acceptable - but thread creation is not free, and if your onInit() method fires of dozens of future loads, you may well see an impact.

        Parameters:
        resource - Basically, a stream containing a texture file. The GVRAndroidResource class has six constructors to handle a wide variety of Android resource types. Taking a GVRAndroidResource here eliminates six overloads.
        Returns:
        A Future that you can pass to methods like GVRShaders.setMainTexture(Future)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If you 'abuse' request consolidation by passing the same GVRAndroidResource descriptor to multiple load calls.

        It's fairly common for multiple scene objects to use the same texture or the same mesh. Thus, if you try to load, say, R.raw.whatever while you already have a pending request for R.raw.whatever, it will only be loaded once; the same resource will be used to satisfy both (all) requests. This "consolidation" uses GVRAndroidResource.equals(Object), not == (aka "reference equality"): The problem with using the same resource descriptor is that if requests can't be consolidated (because the later one(s) came in after the earlier one(s) had already completed) the resource will be reloaded ... but the original descriptor will have been closed.

        Since:
        3.2

      • loadFutureCubemapTexture

        public java.util.concurrent.Future<GVRTexture> loadFutureCubemapTexture(GVRAndroidResource resource)
        Simple, high-level method to load a cube map texture asynchronously, for use with GVRShaders.setMainTexture(Future) and GVRShaders.setTexture(String, Future).
        Parameters:
        resource - A steam containing a zip file which contains six bitmaps. The six bitmaps correspond to +x, -x, +y, -y, +z, and -z faces of the cube map texture respectively. The default names of the six images are "posx.png", "negx.png", "posy.png", "negx.png", "posz.png", and "negz.png", which can be changed by calling GVRCubemapTexture.setFaceNames(String[]).
        Returns:
        A Future that you can pass to methods like GVRShaders.setMainTexture(Future)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If you 'abuse' request consolidation by passing the same GVRAndroidResource descriptor to multiple load calls.

        It's fairly common for multiple scene objects to use the same texture or the same mesh. Thus, if you try to load, say, R.raw.whatever while you already have a pending request for R.raw.whatever, it will only be loaded once; the same resource will be used to satisfy both (all) requests. This "consolidation" uses GVRAndroidResource.equals(Object), not == (aka "reference equality"): The problem with using the same resource descriptor is that if requests can't be consolidated (because the later one(s) came in after the earlier one(s) had already completed) the resource will be reloaded ... but the original descriptor will have been closed.

        Since:
        3.2

      • loadFutureCompressedCubemapTexture

        public java.util.concurrent.Future<GVRTexture> loadFutureCompressedCubemapTexture(GVRAndroidResource resource)
        Simple, high-level method to load a compressed cube map texture asynchronously, for use with GVRShaders.setMainTexture(Future) and GVRShaders.setTexture(String, Future).
        Parameters:
        resource - A steam containing a zip file which contains six compressed textures. The six textures correspond to +x, -x, +y, -y, +z, and -z faces of the cube map texture respectively. The default names of the six images are "posx.pkm", "negx.pkm", "posy.pkm", "negx.pkm", "posz.pkm", and "negz.pkm", which can be changed by calling GVRCubemapTexture.setFaceNames(String[]).
        Returns:
        A Future that you can pass to methods like GVRShaders.setMainTexture(Future)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If you 'abuse' request consolidation by passing the same GVRAndroidResource descriptor to multiple load calls.

        It's fairly common for multiple scene objects to use the same texture or the same mesh. Thus, if you try to load, say, R.raw.whatever while you already have a pending request for R.raw.whatever, it will only be loaded once; the same resource will be used to satisfy both (all) requests. This "consolidation" uses GVRAndroidResource.equals(Object), not == (aka "reference equality"): The problem with using the same resource descriptor is that if requests can't be consolidated (because the later one(s) came in after the earlier one(s) had already completed) the resource will be reloaded ... but the original descriptor will have been closed.

        Since:
        3.2

      • loadTextureAtlasInformation

        public java.util.List<GVRAtlasInformation> loadTextureAtlasInformation(GVRAndroidResource resource)
                                                                throws java.io.IOException
        Loads atlas information file placed in the assets folder. Atlas information file contains in UV space the information of offset and scale for each mesh mapped in some atlas texture. The content of the file is at json format like: [ {name: SUN, offset.x: 0.9, offset.y: 0.9, scale.x: 0.5, scale.y: 0.5}, {name: EARTH, offset.x: 0.5, offset.y: 0.9, scale.x: 0.5, scale.y: 0.5} ]
        Parameters:
        resource - A stream containing a text file on JSON format.
        Returns:
        List of atlas information load.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        Since:
        3.3

      • loadModel

        public GVRModelSceneObject loadModel(java.lang.String filePath)
                              throws java.io.IOException
        Loads a hierarchy of scene objects GVRSceneObject from a 3D model. The model is not added to the current scene. IAssetEvents are emitted to the event listener attached to the context. This function blocks the current thread while loading the model but loads the textures asynchronously in the background.
        Parameters:
        filePath - A filename, relative to the root of the volume. If the filename starts with "sd:" the file is assumed to reside on the SD Card. If the filename starts with "http:" or "https:" it is assumed to be a URL. Otherwise the file is assumed to be relative to the "assets" directory.
        Returns:
        A GVRModelSceneObject that contains the meshes with textures and bones and animations.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if model file cannot be opened

      • loadModel

        public GVRModelSceneObject loadModel(java.lang.String filePath,
                                     GVRScene scene)
                              throws java.io.IOException
        Loads a hierarchy of scene objects GVRSceneObject from a 3D model and adds it to the specified scene. IAssetEvents are emitted to event listeners attached to the context. This function blocks the current thread while loading the model but loads the textures asynchronously in the background.
        Parameters:
        filePath - A filename, relative to the root of the volume. If the filename starts with "sd:" the file is assumed to reside on the SD Card. If the filename starts with "http:" or "https:" it is assumed to be a URL. Otherwise the file is assumed to be relative to the "assets" directory.
        scene - If present, this asset loader will wait until all of the textures have been loaded and then it will add the model to the scene.
        Returns:
        A GVRModelSceneObject that contains the meshes with textures and bones and animations.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • loadScene

        public GVRModelSceneObject loadScene(java.lang.String filePath,
                                     GVRScene scene)
                              throws java.io.IOException
        Loads a hierarchy of scene objects GVRSceneObject from a 3D model replaces the current scene with it. IAssetEvents are emitted to event listeners attached to the context. This function blocks the current thread while loading the model but loads the textures asynchronously in the background.
        Parameters:
        filePath - A filename, relative to the root of the volume. If the filename starts with "sd:" the file is assumed to reside on the SD Card. If the filename starts with "http:" or "https:" it is assumed to be a URL. Otherwise the file is assumed to be relative to the "assets" directory.
        scene - Scene to be replaced with the model.
        Returns:
        A GVRModelSceneObject that contains the meshes with textures and bones and animations.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • loadScene

        public void loadScene(GVRSceneObject model,
                      GVRResourceVolume volume,
                      GVRScene scene,
                      IAssetEvents handler)
        Loads a hierarchy of scene objects GVRSceneObject from a 3D model replaces the current scene with it. This function loads the model and its textures asynchronously in the background and will return before the model is loaded. IAssetEvents are emitted to event listeners attached to the context.
        Parameters:
        model - Scene object to become the root of the loaded model. This scene object will be named with the base filename of the loaded asset.
        volume - A GVRResourceVolume based on the asset path to load. This volume will be used as the base for loading textures and other models contained within the model. You can subclass GVRResourceVolume to provide custom IO.
        scene - Scene to be replaced with the model.
        handler - IAssetEvents handler to process asset loading events

      • loadScene

        public void loadScene(GVRSceneObject model,
                      GVRResourceVolume volume,
                      java.util.EnumSet<GVRImportSettings> settings,
                      GVRScene scene,
                      IAssetEvents handler)
        Loads a hierarchy of scene objects GVRSceneObject from a 3D model replaces the current scene with it. This function loads the model and its textures asynchronously in the background and will return before the model is loaded. IAssetEvents are emitted to event listeners attached to the context.
        Parameters:
        model - Scene object to become the root of the loaded model. This scene object will be named with the base filename of the loaded asset.
        volume - A GVRResourceVolume based on the asset path to load. This volume will be used as the base for loading textures and other models contained within the model. You can subclass GVRResourceVolume to provide custom IO.
        settings - Import settings controlling how assets are imported
        scene - Scene to be replaced with the model.
        handler - IAssetEvents handler to process asset loading events

      • loadModel

        public void loadModel(GVRSceneObject model,
                      GVRResourceVolume volume,
                      GVRScene scene)
        Loads a hierarchy of scene objects GVRSceneObject from a 3D model on the volume provided and adds it to the specified scene. IAssetEvents are emitted to event listeners attached to the context. This function loads the model and its textures asynchronously in the background and will return before the model is loaded. IAssetEvents are emitted to event listeners attached to the context. The resource volume may reference res/raw in which case all textures and other referenced assets must also come from res/raw. The asset loader cannot loadtextures from the drawable directory.
        Parameters:
        model - A GVRSceneObject to become the root of the loaded model.
        volume - A GVRResourceVolume based on the asset path to load. This volume will be used as the base for loading textures and other models contained within the model. You can subclass GVRResourceVolume to provide custom IO.
        scene - If present, this asset loader will wait until all of the textures have been loaded and then it will add the model to the scene.

      • loadModel

        public void loadModel(GVRSceneObject model,
                      GVRResourceVolume volume,
                      java.util.EnumSet<GVRImportSettings> settings,
                      GVRScene scene)
        Loads a hierarchy of scene objects GVRSceneObject from a 3D model on the volume provided and adds it to the specified scene. IAssetEvents are emitted to event listeners attached to the context. This function loads the model and its textures asynchronously in the background and will return before the model is loaded. IAssetEvents are emitted to event listeners attached to the context. The resource volume may reference res/raw in which case all textures and other referenced assets must also come from res/raw. The asset loader cannot loadtextures from the drawable directory.
        Parameters:
        model - A GVRSceneObject to become the root of the loaded model.
        volume - A GVRResourceVolume based on the asset path to load. This volume will be used as the base for loading textures and other models contained within the model. You can subclass GVRResourceVolume to provide custom IO.
        scene - If present, this asset loader will wait until all of the textures have been loaded and then it will add the model to the scene.
        settings - Import settings controlling how assets are imported

      • loadModel

        public GVRModelSceneObject loadModel(java.lang.String filePath,
                                     IAssetEvents handler)
                              throws java.io.IOException
        Loads a hierarchy of scene objects GVRSceneObject from a 3D model. The model is not added to the current scene. IAssetEvents are emitted to the event handler supplied first and then to the event listener attached to the context. This function blocks the current thread while loading the model but loads the textures asynchronously in the background.
        Parameters:
        filePath - A filename, relative to the root of the volume. If the filename starts with "sd:" the file is assumed to reside on the SD Card. If the filename starts with "http:" or "https:" it is assumed to be a URL. Otherwise the file is assumed to be relative to the "assets" directory.
        handler - IAssetEvents handler to process asset loading events
        Returns:
        A GVRModelSceneObject that contains the meshes with textures and bones and animations.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • loadModel

        public GVRModelSceneObject loadModel(java.lang.String filePath,
                                     java.util.EnumSet<GVRImportSettings> settings,
                                     boolean cacheEnabled,
                                     GVRScene scene)
                              throws java.io.IOException

        cacheEnabled - If true, add the model's textures to the texture cache.
        scene - If present, this asset loader will wait until all of the textures have been loaded and then adds the model to the scene.

        Throws:

      • loadModel

        public GVRModelSceneObject loadModel(GVRAndroidResource resource,
                                     java.util.EnumSet<GVRImportSettings> settings,
                                     boolean cacheEnabled,
                                     GVRScene scene)
                              throws java.io.IOException
        Loads a hierarchy of scene objects GVRSceneObject from a 3D model inside an Android resource. cannot load textures from the drawable directory. The model is not added to the current scene. IAssetEvents are emitted to the event handler supplied first and then to the event listener attached to the context. This function blocks the current thread while loading the model but loads the textures asynchronously in the background. The resource may be from res/raw in which case all textures and other referenced assets must also come from res/raw. The asset loader cannot load textures referenced from within 3D models from the drawable directory.
        Parameters:
        resource - GVRAndroidResource describing the asset. If it is a resource ID, the file it references must have a valid extension because the extension is used to determine what type of 3D file it is.
        settings - Additional import settings
        cacheEnabled - If true, add the model's textures to the texture cache.
        scene - If present, this asset loader will wait until all of the textures have been loaded and then adds the model to the scene.
        Returns:
        A GVRModelSceneObject that contains the meshes with textures and bones and animations.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • loadModel

        public void loadModel(GVRResourceVolume fileVolume,
                      GVRSceneObject model,
                      java.util.EnumSet<GVRImportSettings> settings,
                      boolean cacheEnabled,
                      IAssetEvents handler)
        Loads a scene object GVRSceneObject from a 3D model and raises asset events to a handler.
        Parameters:
        fileVolume - GVRResourceVolume with the path to the model to load. The filename is relative to the root of this volume. The volume will be used to load models referenced by this model.
        model - GVRModelSceneObject that is the root of the hierarchy generated by loading the 3D model.
        settings - Additional import settings
        cacheEnabled - If true, add the model's textures to the texture cache
        handler - IAssetEvents handler to process asset loading events

      • loadMesh

        public GVRMesh loadMesh(GVRAndroidResource androidResource)
        Loads a file as a GVRMesh. Note that this method can be quite slow; we recommend never calling it from the GL thread. The asynchronous version loadMesh(GVRAndroidResource.MeshCallback, GVRAndroidResource, int) is better because it moves most of the work to a background thread, doing as little as possible on the GL thread.
        Parameters:
        androidResource - Basically, a stream containing a 3D model. The GVRAndroidResource class has six constructors to handle a wide variety of Android resource types. Taking a GVRAndroidResource here eliminates six overloads.
        Returns:
        The file as a GL mesh or null if mesh cannot be loaded.
        Since:
        1.6.2

      • loadMesh

        public GVRMesh loadMesh(GVRAndroidResource androidResource,
                        java.util.EnumSet<GVRImportSettings> settings)
        Loads a GVRMesh from a 3D asset file synchronously.

        It uses loadModel(GVRAndroidResource, EnumSet, boolean, GVRScene) internally to load the asset and then inspects the file to find the first mesh. Note that this method can be quite slow; we recommend never calling it from the GL thread. The asynchronous version loadMesh(GVRAndroidResource.MeshCallback, GVRAndroidResource, int) is better because it moves most of the work to a background thread, doing as little as possible on the GL thread.

        Parameters:
        androidResource - Basically, a stream containing a 3D model. The GVRAndroidResource class has six constructors to handle a wide variety of Android resource types. Taking a GVRAndroidResource here eliminates six overloads.
        settings - Additional import settings.
        Returns:
        The file as a GL mesh or null if mesh cannot be loaded.
        Since:
        3.3

      • loadMesh

        public void loadMesh(GVRAndroidResource.MeshCallback callback,
                     GVRAndroidResource resource,
                     int priority)
              throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Loads a mesh file, asynchronously, at an explicit priority.

        This method is generally going to be your best choices for loading a single mesh from a 3D asset file. It uses loadModel(GVRAndroidResource, EnumSet, boolean, GVRScene) internally to load the asset and then inspects the file to find the first mesh.

        Mesh loading can take hundreds - and even thousands - of milliseconds, and so should not be done on the GL thread in either onInit() or onStep().

        The asynchronous methods improve throughput in three ways. First, by doing all the work on a background thread, then delivering the loaded mesh to the GL thread on a runOnGlThread() callback. Second, they use a throttler to avoid overloading the system and/or running out of memory. Third, they do 'request consolidation' - if you issue any requests for a particular file while there is still a pending request, the file will only be read once, and each callback will get the same GVRMesh.

        Parameters:
        callback - App supplied callback, with three different methods.
        • Before loading, GVRF may call stillWanted() (on a background thread) to give you a chance to abort a 'stale' load.
        • Successful loads will call loaded() on the GL thread.
        • Any errors will call failed(), with no promises about threading.
        resource - Basically, a stream containing a 3D model. The GVRAndroidResource class has six constructors to handle a wide variety of Android resource types. Taking a GVRAndroidResource here eliminates six overloads.
        priority - This request's priority. Please see the notes on asynchronous priorities in the package description.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If either callback or resource is null, or if priority is out of range - or if you 'abuse' request consolidation by passing the same GVRAndroidResource descriptor to multiple load calls.

        It's fairly common for multiple scene objects to use the same texture or the same mesh. Thus, if you try to load, say, R.raw.whatever while you already have a pending request for R.raw.whatever, it will only be loaded once; the same resource will be used to satisfy both (all) requests. This "consolidation" uses GVRAndroidResource.equals(Object), not == (aka "reference equality"): The problem with using the same resource descriptor is that if requests can't be consolidated (because the later one(s) came in after the earlier one(s) had already completed) the resource will be reloaded ... but the original descriptor will have been closed.

        Since:
        3.3

      • loadFutureMesh

        public java.util.concurrent.Future<GVRMesh> loadFutureMesh(GVRAndroidResource resource)
        Simple, high-level method to load a mesh asynchronously, for use with GVRRenderData.setMesh(Future). This method uses a default priority; use loadFutureMesh(GVRAndroidResource, int) to specify a priority; use one of the lower-level loadMesh(GVRAndroidResource.MeshCallback, GVRAndroidResource, int) methods to get more control over loading.
        Parameters:
        resource - Basically, a stream containing a 3D model. The GVRAndroidResource class has six constructors to handle a wide variety of Android resource types. Taking a GVRAndroidResource here eliminates six overloads.
        Returns:
        A Future that you can pass to GVRRenderData.setMesh(Future)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If you 'abuse' request consolidation by passing the same GVRAndroidResource descriptor to multiple load calls.

        It's fairly common for multiple scene objects to use the same texture or the same mesh. Thus, if you try to load, say, R.raw.whatever while you already have a pending request for R.raw.whatever, it will only be loaded once; the same resource will be used to satisfy both (all) requests. This "consolidation" uses GVRAndroidResource.equals(Object), not == (aka "reference equality"): The problem with using the same resource descriptor is that if requests can't be consolidated (because the later one(s) came in after the earlier one(s) had already completed) the resource will be reloaded ... but the original descriptor will have been closed.

        Since:
        3.3

      • loadFutureMesh

        public java.util.concurrent.Future<GVRMesh> loadFutureMesh(GVRAndroidResource resource,
                                                           int priority)
        Simple, high-level method to load a mesh asynchronously, for use with GVRRenderData.setMesh(Future). This method trades control for convenience; use one of the lower-level loadMesh(GVRAndroidResource.MeshCallback, GVRAndroidResource, int) methods if, say, you want to do something more than just GVRRenderData.setMesh(GVRMesh) when the mesh loads.
        Parameters:
        resource - Basically, a stream containing a 3D model. The GVRAndroidResource class has six constructors to handle a wide variety of Android resource types. Taking a GVRAndroidResource here eliminates six overloads.
        priority - This request's priority. Please see the notes on asynchronous priorities in the package description.
        Returns:
        A Future that you can pass to GVRRenderData.setMesh(Future)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If you 'abuse' request consolidation by passing the same GVRAndroidResource descriptor to multiple load calls.

        It's fairly common for multiple scene objects to use the same texture or the same mesh. Thus, if you try to load, say, R.raw.whatever while you already have a pending request for R.raw.whatever, it will only be loaded once; the same resource will be used to satisfy both (all) requests. This "consolidation" uses GVRAndroidResource.equals(Object), not == (aka "reference equality"): The problem with using the same resource descriptor is that if requests can't be consolidated (because the later one(s) came in after the earlier one(s) had already completed) the resource will be reloaded ... but the original descriptor will have been closed.

        Since:
        3.3
